docs.lead_paragraph: McKesson HBOC, the largest United States drug wholesaler, has formed an Internet unit that will sell software and services aimed at helping doctors use the Web to manage their offices. The iMcKesson health care unit will have about 2,000 employees and be led by the McKesson co-chief executive David L. Mahoney. McKesson's other co-chief executive, John H. Hammergren, will oversee the company's pharmaceutical services, information technology and supply management groups.

headline.main: McKesson Starts an Internet Medical Service

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly a million low-income parents have lost Medicaid coverage and have probably become uninsured since Congress and the states began overhauling the nation's welfare programs in 1996, a consumer group said in a new study today. The group, Families USA, said the number of low-income parents enrolled in Medicaid in 15 states had declined by 945,880, or 27 percent -- to 2,557,673 in December 1999, from 3,503,553 in January 1996.

headline.main: A Million Parents Lost Medicaid, Study Says

docs.abstract: New study by consumer group Families USA says nearly million low-income parents have lost Medicaid coverage and have probably become uninsured since Congress and states began overhauling nation's welfare programs in 1996; says number of low-income parents enrolled in Medicaid in 15 states declined by 945,880, or 27 percent, to 2,557,673 in December 1999, from 3,503,553 in January 1996; states are home to 70 percent of uninsured adults who are under 65 and have incomes less than twice poverty level, or $23,300 for family of three; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Nearly a million low-income parents have lost Medicaid coverage and have probably become uninsured since Congress and the states began overhauling the nation's welfare programs in 1996, a consumer group said in a new study today.    The group,...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled today that a recent law that suspends certain federal court orders governing conditions in state and local prisons does not amount to an unconstitutional interference by Congress into the business of the federal courts. The 5-to-4 decision upheld a provision of the Prison Litigation Reform Act under which judges must either rule on the continuing validity of an ongoing prison injunction within 90 days -- when its validity is challenged by the state or anyone else -- or find the injunction automatically suspended until they do rule.

headline.main: Congress's Challenge to Judges Is Upheld
headline.kicker: THE SUPREME COURT: SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP

docs.abstract: US Supreme Court rules recent law that suspends certain federal court orders governing conditions in state and local prisons does not amount to unconstitutional interference by Congress into business of federal courts; vacates and sends back to Pennsylvania Supreme Court case in which state court allowed medical negligence case against health maintenance organization United States Healthcare Systems to proceed because organization refused to authorize member's admission to nearest hospital, which was not plan participant; will decide whether--when free speech interests are at stake--Constitution requires prompt judicial determination of challenge to state or local licensing law; case is appeal by owner of adult bookstore in Waukesha, Wis, challenging city's refusal to renew store's operating license in proceeding that lasted many months (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: The time has come to get more people enrolled in Medicaid. Every child in New York State should have health insurance. It is a really good idea to raise the amount of income people on government-sponsored insurance can earn. Interestingly enough, these are not the quaint policy suggestions of liberal public servants or advocates for the poor, but rather plans of action ordered up in recent months by the Republican mayor of New York City and the Republican governor of New York, both of whom, not so long ago, championed policies that in some respects were in direct opposition to these notions.

headline.main: For Giuliani and Pataki, About-Face on Health Issues

docs.abstract: Analysis of shift by Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani and Gov George E Pataki away from trying to cut Medicaid, health insurance program for poor, toward trying to enroll more New Yorkers in program; notes shift has dazzled and confounded some of their critics; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lorraine Lacaillade, a 75-year-old widow in Bolton, about 25 miles southeast of here, lives on about $12,000 a year, most of it from Social Security. She takes prescription drugs for arthritis and other conditions that would cost more than $1,000 a year if she had to pay for them herself. But this is Vermont, a state in the vanguard of offering health benefits to its residents. Under the Vermont Health Access Plan, a program for people who are earning just enough to make ends meet, Mrs. Lacaillade only pays $3 a month for her medicine.

headline.main: Expansion of Medical Benefits Puts Vermont in the Vanguard

docs.abstract: Vermont is in vanguard in offering health benefits to residents, with benefits unmatched elsewhere in US; 93.5 percent of all residents have health insurance, including essentially all children; array of health benefits offered by state discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE 202,000-SQUARE-FOOT industrial building here at the intersection of Broad Hollow and Baylis Roads is scheduled to join a growing number of similar buildings in the Route 110 corridor that have been converted to prime office space. The Marcus Organization of Hauppauge is in contract to buy the building -- the address is 515 Broad Hollow Road -- and it intends to rename it Melville Center. The closing is to take place in the fall after two of three leases held by current tenants expire, and plans are to redo the facade and to renovate the interior to suit the new tenants as leases are signed. The entire project is expected to be completed in the first quarter of next year.

headline.main: In the Region/Long Island; Along Rt. 110, Industrial Buildings Become Offices

docs.lead_paragraph: With the House about to begin two weeks of intense debate over competing proposals to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, the differences between President Clinton and Republicans in Congress are widening by the day. Medicare drug benefits have emerged as one of the more potent political issues in this year's elections, as lawmakers and candidates continually hear voters complain about high drug costs. Both parties say their goal is to make drug coverage available and affordable to Medicare beneficiaries in every corner of the United States.

headline.main: PARTY DIFFERENCES ON DRUG BENEFITS CONTINUE TO GROW

docs.abstract: Differences widen between Pres Clinton and Republicans in Congress over adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare; Republicans want more choices and options for beneficiaries, larger role for private insurance companies, and smaller role and lower costs for government; Democrats want more uniformity in premiums and benefits; they say Republicans' free-market approach will confuse beneficiaries and encourage insurers to seek out healthy customers with relatively low drug costs, practice known as cherry-picking; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: With the House about to begin two weeks of intense debate over competing proposals to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, the differences between President Clinton and Republicans in Congress are widening by the day.    Medicare drug benefits...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is not surprising that the citizens of Massachusetts have decided to take matters to the ballot box since patients' bills of rights have been stymied in committee at both the federal and state levels (front page, June 11). The frustrations of doctors, nurses, mental health care professionals, social workers, administrators and patients continue to be voiced in meetings of organizations like the Ad Hoc Committee to Defend Health Care. These frustrations will most likely lead to a favorable vote in November despite the opposition's spending millions of our health care premium dollars to try to defeat the initiative.
docs.abstract: Dr Kenneth E Smith letter responds to June 11 front-page article on Massachusetts referendum on patients' bill of rights; asserts patients should be placed above profits in health care system

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: I am a physician in a trauma center that does not check accident victims for alcohol and drugs. If a driver were intoxicated, insurance would not cover medical costs. However, not knowing blood- alcohol levels may have adverse medical consequences. Should we check even if it means added financial burdens, suboptimal care or exposure to criminal charges? -- Anonymous, New York A doctor is pledged to do what is in the patient's best interest medically. So check blood-alcohol levels, but do not disclose this information -- neither to cops nor insurance companies -- without the patient's consent. The A.M.A.'s confidentiality policy is meant to protect individual patients, not to promote public health, aid law enforcement or reduce insurance rates.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 6-18-00: The Ethicist; Blood Work

docs.abstract: Randy Cohen The Ethicist question-and-answer column on ethics of doctor not checking accident victims for alcohol and drugs to protect their health insurance coverage at possible risk to their health; also responds to classic moral dilemma presented to business students (M)
